docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Breakout Principle,'' by Dr. Herbert Benson and William Proctor. Scribner, $25. Rebecca, the subject of a case history in this self-help book, often found herself with writer's block. To break through what stood in her way of rescuing a character from a tight spot, she stopped work and walk-jogged to a favorite seaside locale.
docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School Dr Herbert Benson and William Proctor book Breakout Principledescribes concept of breakout mind-body relationship and ways to use triggers to activate life-altering revelations; uses case history to exemplify concepts; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fatigue and even a legally permissible amount of alcohol can combine dangerously for drivers, a British study has found, especially because the young men being tested appeared to be unaware of their increased impairment. After getting five hours of sleep, 12 men who had the equivalent of two glasses of beer with lunch drifted out of their lanes an average of 32 times in a simulated two-hour highway drive.
docs.abstract: Dr Jim Horne, Loughborough University (Liechestershire, Eng), leads research published in Occupational and Environmental Medicine, British Medical Association journal, that shows even legal amounts of alcohol combined with fatigue substantially increase risk of driving accidents; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Fatigue and even a legally permissible amount of alcohol can combine dangerously for drivers, a British study has found, especially because the young men being tested appeared to be unaware of their increased impairment.    After getting five hours...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ha Nguyen, a 23-year-old research assistant, walked into the Andre Chreky salon here, slipped into a silky green smock and sat for a haircut. Nothing unusual about that. But Ms. Nguyen's thick straight black hair, nearly two feet long from crown to end, was not destined for the floor and the trash. She had been growing it for more than two years for the express purpose of donating it to a foundation that prepares wigs made of real hair for young people who are bald.

headline.main: Volunteer Donors Step In When Disease Robs Children of Their Hair

docs.abstract: Locks of Love executive director Susan Stone explains core purpose to supply wigs to children from low income families who have suffered permanent hair loss; most that apply have alopecia areata, but all types of disorders affecting hair are given consideration; personal gift of hair by research assistant Ha Nguyen is described; process of making hairpieces by Taylormade, wig company, is described; photos (M)
